ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NATIONAL SERVICE
(Deferment and Part-time)


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister of Defence how many applications were made (i) for deferment; and (ii) for part-time National Service, during the year ending 28th February, 1973; how many applications were approved; and how many applications were rejected and the reasons therefor.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Defence (Mr Phua Bah Lee) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, between 1st March, 1972, and 28th February, 1973, 878 applications were received for exemption/deferment from full-time National Service. Of this number, 146 were applications for deferment and 732 were applications for part-time National Service. The decisions in respect of these applications were as follows:- 
 

     Number granted part-time service    394

     Number granted deferment            117

                                         --- 

     Total appeals granted               511

                                         ===

     Number not approved                 326

     Number being investigated            41


    Applications are considered on the following grounds:

    (a) Whether call-up for full-time National Service will result in financial hardship for the family.

    (b) Whether it will result in the disintegration of a business enterprise.

These applications are referred to an Advisory Board consisting of prominent members of the public (including businessmen and senior public servants) and senior military officers. Those applications in which these grounds are not satisfied are rejected.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Parliamentary Secretary please inform the House

Column: 1026

whether all applications are, in fact, referred to the Advisory Board?

    Mr Phua Bah Lee: Mr Speaker, Sir, when applications for deferment or for part-time service are received at the Central Manpower Base, they are examined to see what grounds have been given. If they conform to the grounds which I have stated earlier, such as financial hardship or disintegration of a business, the applications are referred to the Advisory Board for consideration. This Advisory Board will then review such cases, and their recommendations are submitted to the Director of Manpower. Each application is, therefore, considered on its own merits.

CRASH HELMETS
(Fatal accidents since Legislation)


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Communications, since the wearing of crash helmets by motor cyclists and scooterists was made compulsory, how many such persons have died in road accidents.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Dr Ang Kok Peng) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, compulsory wearing of crash helmets was implemented in three stages. In the first stage, only those applying for new provisional licences for motor-cycles and scooters were required to wear crash helmets with effect from 1st November, 1969. The second stage came into effect from 1st February, 1970, when all provisional licence holders for motor-cycles and scooters were required to wear crash helmets. It was only in the third stage, from 1st January, 1971, that all motor-cyclists, scooterists and pillion-riders were required to wear crash helmets.

    In 1970, there were 118 fatal accidents involving motor-cyclists and scooterists. There were 77 fatal cases in 1971, and 73 fatal cases in 1972. This represents a decrease of 35 per cent in fatal cases in 1971, and a decrease of 38 per cent in 1972, when compared with the number of fatal accidents involving motor-cyclists

Column: 1027

and scooterists in 1970, when "L" riders were required to wear crash helmets.

    Head 1501 --

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1501 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Tay Boon Too, Ho Kah Leong and P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, recently the Government has initiated some very welcome measures by revising the leave eligibility of civil servants and by introducing realistic incentives for top civil servants. The much publicised reason for the introduction of these measures is to make the terms and conditions of service in the public sector comparable with those prevailing in the private sector. However, the Government has made it known that employees in the Education service are to be excluded from the benefits of the various schemes recently introduced by the Government to attract and to retain the best in the public service. In so doing, the Government has, in fact, created further anomalies in the terms and conditions of service for different groups of employees in the public sector and has, therefore, effectively nullified all its past attempts to establish the principles of fair comparison and internal relativity within the public service as an objective basis in determining the terms and conditions of work in the public service.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I will now refer the Education Minister to the recent scheme of the Government whereby a monthly allowance is to be paid to employees in the public service as compensation for the reduction of their annual leave and medical leave eligibility. Such a realistic scheme is much to be welcomed, except

Column: 1029

that the Government has declared that all employees in the Education service are to be excluded from the scheme.

    Under the revised scheme, in respect of medical leave eligibility, all public officers can opt either for the maximum medical leave eligibility under the old scheme without any monetary allowance, or for a reduced leave eligibility plus a monetary allowance equivalent to ten days' pay. The full medical leave eligibility is a nominal benefit of which a very small proportion of public employees have availed themselves to the whole extent. As far as possible, they prefer to be spared the circumstances whereby they have to utilise any portion of their hospitalisation leave eligibility.

    Under the revised scheme, therefore, those public officers who normally do not fully utilise their leave eligibility will, by opting to participate in the scheme, gain by converting their surplus portion of leave eligibility, which is a contingent interest, into an entitlement of a monetary allowance equivalent to ten days' pay. The exclusion of education officers from participation under the scheme in respect of the conversion of surplus medical leave eligibility into a monetary allowance results in a positive disadvantage to education officers in comparison with their colleagues in the administrative and executive services.

    In respect of the abovementioned scheme, the decision of the Government to exclude officers in the Education service from the scheme seems to be based on an oversight. While officers in the Education service generally do not enjoy any annual leave eligibility, they do have the same medical leave eligibility as their colleagues in the administrative and executive services of the Government.

    I am of the view, therefore, that all officers in the Education service, whether performing teaching or administrative duties, should be accorded an opportunity to opt for a payment of a special monthly allowance in lieu of a greater medical leave eligibility.

    In respect of the revised scheme on annual leave eligibility, the decision of

Column: 1030

the Government to exclude persons in the Education service seems to be based on the assumption that all persons in the Education service have no annual leave eligibility and that, as such, they cannot opt for any reduction in their annual leave eligibility to qualify for the special monthly allowance. I agree that such an assumption is accurate and justifiable in respect of the majority of the persons in the education service.

    There is, however, a minority of persons in the Education service who are attached to the Headquarters in the Ministry of Education. Such education officers have the same hours of work and similar annual leave eligibility as their colleagues who are in the administrative or the executive service. I am of the view that these education officers who are accorded an annual leave eligibility by reason of their administrative or special functions should be permitted to opt for a special monthly allowance in consideration for a reduced annual leave eligibility under the scheme.

    While an objection may be raised against the inclusion of such officers in the scheme on the ground that postings to the Headquarters of the Ministry are not of a permanent duration and that the officers so posted may sooner or later be transferred back to teaching duties in schools, in practice the possibility of officers who have been assigned administrative or special duties being transferred back to teaching duties, is very remote. Even if I concede that such transfers may and do take place, there is no reason that the officers so affected cannot be accorded whatever special monthly allowance may be payable under the scheme for so long as they are required to perform administrative or special functions and to observe the same working hours and other working conditions as their office colleagues in the administrative or executive service.

    I now refer the Education Minister to the Ministerial Statement of his colleague, the Finance Minister, on 16th February, 1973 in this House in which he stated that a Merit Increment Scheme for civil servants will be introduced and that the upper timescale will be revised

Column: 1031

from $l,700x50-1,850 to $l,700x100-2,000.

2.45 p.m.

    In the Education service structure, there are nine salary scales, the highest of which is the scale of $1,700x50-1,850. A teacher who starts at the bottom of the Education service will have to secure eight promotions before he can expect to be placed on this scale. This scale is identical and corresponds to the upper timescale. It is only logical that revision of the upper timescale must result in the revision of this scale.

    The introduction of a Merit Increment Scheme by Government is to retain and to attract the best in the civil service. I am sure Members in this House will agree with me that the need to retain and to attract the best in the Education service is just as crucial and vital as the need to retain and to attract the best in the other sectors of the public service. Unless the Education Ministry has strong objections to granting increments to teachers, I urge the Government to reconsider its decision and not to create a "Cinderella" out of the Education service.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, recently a case of errors in translation was found among textbooks approved by the Ministry of Education. Moreover, some of these books were edited in a haphazard manner. As a school teacher, I would like to speak on this point.

    First, I would like to deal with the textbooks. We all know that irrespective of the teaching method adopted, the textbook remains one of the main tools for teaching and imparting knowledge. The textbook is a medium for teaching and learning. If a textbook is full of errors, the teacher will have to spend a lot of his time reading other books to supplement the material contained in the main textbook. And if it is a textbook edited in a haphazard manner, the teacher will also have to spend a lot of his time teaching without the use of the textbook.

Column: 1032



    In a recent case, we found many translation errors in a textbook. The teacher had to waste his time correcting these errors. At the same time, it demoralises the teacher and the pupils. Some confusion and misunderstanding must result from these translation errors. Sir, these errors have caused untold damage and irreparable harm. To the younger generation, the textbook is a very important medium of knowledge and we should pay serious attention to this matter. On discovery of these translation errors, the Ministry of Education immediately announced that it would take immediate measures to prevent a recurrence of such errors.

    Sir, in the last few years we have spent large sums of money on education. The expenditure on Education is second only to Defence. Therefore, why is it that the Ministry of Education has still not established a committee for the translation and editing of textbooks? As an educationist, I hope that the Ministry of Education will look into this matter. Of course, what's done is done. But it is better late than never. I think the Ministry should consider setting up an independent committee on textbooks, so that it will absorb the present employees and staff of the Ministry who are responsible for the publication of textbooks. At the same time, people with specialist knowledge and wide teaching experience can come forward to assist this committee. This committee can, in addition to editing the textbooks for the primary and secondary schools, also review all the textbooks currently in use in the schools. The purpose of the review is to ensure that there are no further cases of errors and also to make an improvement to the textbook, if necessary. We know that the contents if textbooks will affect the spirit and attitude of both the teacher and the pupils, and the wrong textbooks will therefore lead to confusion and misunderstanding.

    Sir, at this juncture, I would also like to raise a few other points, one of which is in regard to the administration of the Ministry of Education. Although

Column: 1033

the Ministry is in charge of education in the four language streams, 95 per cent of the correspondence from the Ministry is written in English. I am not raising the question of language. The Government has laid down the policy of multi-lingualism. Why is it that the Ministry of Education, which has so many talented officers, cannot translate official correspondence into the other official languages? Of course, if the correspondence is addressed to English schools it is quite logical and understandable. But the question is this. When correspondence in English is addressed to schools which do not use English as the medium of instruction, then time is wasted by the school staff in understanding it and getting it translated. I trust, Sir, that from now on the Ministry will be able to use all the four official languages in its correspondence and its circulars to all schools in the four language streams.

    Sir, during the debate on the President's Address, I had spoken about the retirement age of teachers in Government-aided schools. At that time, perhaps the Minister for Education was not present. But up to now, I have still not received any reply. Now that the Minister is present, I do not know whether he has looked up the relevant copy of the Hansard on this matter so that he can give me a reply. If he has not, may I be permitted to repeat what I said on that occasion, i.e, that all Government-aided school teachers should be given the opportunity to retire at the age of 60 years. I hope the Minister will now give me a reply one way or the other.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another point is in respect of schools in the rural areas. Some of them are so small that they do not even have a school clerk. Sometimes the principal himself has to teach and to do the administrative and clerical work. I do not understand why the Ministry cannot provide a clerk for a small rural school, which has the same amount of administrative work as the larger schools. Up to now I have not received any reply. I hope the Minister will be able to give me a

Column: 1034

reply. I also hope that by tomorrow these schools will be provided with clerks.

    Finally, I would like to touch on the question of medical benefits for teachers in Government-aided schools. By doing so, I am not saying that they are not contented. We are most grateful indeed to the Ministry for giving us the same medical benefits as the Government teachers. But there is still some difference to a certain extent. In the case of Government teachers, after their retirement, they will continue to enjoy medical benefits.

    But the teachers in Government-aided schools do not qualify for free medical benefits after retirement. What is the reason for this difference? Both are doing the same work and living in the same country. This is not to say that the teachers in aided schools are not contented with what have been accorded to them. While a young man, he is strong and healthy and is not likely to suffer from any illness. It is only on occasions that he might have minor ailments like a cold or flu. But when he is old, he may have health problems. Many Government-aided school teachers suffer from ill-health after retirement. The older they are, the more troubles they have. These old people, who have devoted 20 to 30 years of their lives in the Education service of the country suffer a poor fate after retirement. I hope that the Minister concerned will sympathetically consider the plight of the aided-school teachers.

    The Chairman: Mr Tay, I have allowed you more than 10 minutes. When are you going to finish your speech?

    Mr Tay Boon Too: Sir, I have already finished. (in Mandarin) The main point is that after he passes away, the medical benefit is withdrawn!

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, over the past few years the Ministry of Education seems to be very busy taking note

Column: 1035

of the ages of old teachers in Singapore. Those teachers who have reached the age of 40 years and 50 years or more have to report their ages to the Ministry of Education. It is as if the Ministry of Education is afraid that they will stay on to teach for one day more than is necessary.

    There have been many applications from the retired teachers for extension of service. Some applications have been granted on a three-month or six-month basis, and only a very fortunate few are granted an extension of one year. Unfortunately, some teachers are only allowed to get 80 per cent of their last drawn pay when they are so-called "re-employed". I think this is a bit ridiculous. Since we allow these teachers to extend their services, that means we consider their services useful, valid and effective. Since they are useful and effective teachers, why should their salary be reduced by 20 per cent? To an old teacher who has dedicated his whole life to education, this is a great blow to him morally. Unlike people in other professions, teachers start their professional work at a late age because of their professional training. These teachers are brain workers. But if they are forced to retire at the age of 50 which, according to experts, is the maturity age, and this also is the important stage of the teachers' career, then this will not only be a great loss to the teachers themselves but also a loss to the country. It is my hope that the Minister will sympathetically consider the applications from teachers for extension of service, and that on re-employment their salaries should not be reduced by 20 per cent.

    The Member for Paya Lebar has brought up the question of textbooks, and I would like to add my views to what he has said. There has been quite a lot of criticisms against textbooks published locally. While we here are not concerned as to whether this is the result of some overt or covert rivalry between publishers in the private sector, such criticisms have brought into

Column: 1036

the open the defect in the present review system of textbooks. Sir, textbooks are not to be regarded as bibles. However, there is no doubt that they form the basis of teaching and learning. Therefore, if there are any defects in them, they will be very unreliable.

    I fully endorse that there should be freedom of publication, because if there is freedom of publication there will be competition, and if there is competition there will be improvement. But this should not be taken haphazardly or done in a very irresponsible manner, particularly in regard to textbooks for schools. I would like to take this opportunity therefore to propose that henceforth book publishers or book-shops should be asked to set up a textbook editorial committee with such members to be approved by the Ministry of Education. In this way, we can prevent publishers or bookshops from getting anyone they choose within a short time. Next, the Ministry of Education should also set up a committee consisting of experts in their own field, such as specialist inspectors and representatives from the various teachers' associations. We cannot continue with the present system of giving $50 to each textbook reviewer and expect good result. In fairness, we should also ensure that adequate time is given to the compilers or editors of textbooks. We cannot expect these people to produce good textbooks within six months of the publication of the syllabuses, because the publication of textbooks involves not only editing, printing, but also research. So we cannot rush out a good textbook in any case.

    Finally I would like to suggest to the Minister that prices of textbooks should be rationalised so that there would be no undue profiteering by publishers and bookshops.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the abolition of history and geography from Primary VII exanimations has been a very wise move on the part of this Ministry. The increase in the number of passes in Primary VI is a clear indication of the wisdom of this move. As a result of

Column: 1037

the large number of passes, we have a unique system introduced in secondary schools. We have such a thing as "floating" classes. Literally they are floating, for the students have no firm classroom which they can claim as their own, and as a result we have a class of pupils who are without a permanent place in the school. I wonder how long these "floating" classes will go on. What we need urgently are extensions to accommodate more classes, and this is not an impossible task.

    Last year, I brought the attention of the Minister to the sad state of affairs of Secondary I and II students. Not only have they got to learn 11 compulsory examination subjects, but they also have to go for workshop practices twice weekly, and for extra-curricular activities two or three times a week. How on earth can these young minds cope with this enormous work-load?

    Since the removal of history and geography from Primary VI examinations has concretely proved better results, would it not also be wise to remove history and geography from examinations in Secondary I and II? This will lighten their load a great deal, and probably we may eventually be able to produce better results in Secondary IV and HSC levels.

    What is the Education Ministry's policy regarding transfers? I thought the policy is to reduce transfers to the minimum. Yet we still find teachers being transferred within 24 hours. How can teachers in Government schools be expected to be fully loyal to the school, if they realise that they can be transferred within 24 hours merely upon a telephone call? Is this the way the Ministry runs its establishment? Has it no consideration for the teachers? Or have the officers working in air-conditioned comfort become so inhumane, as to think of teachers as mere digits in their files? I urge the Minister to give more valued consideration to the transfer of teachers against their

Column: 1038

wishes, and to consider the human aspect of the action more than just filling in the gap in a staffing list.

    Why are teachers made to do two compulsory extra-curricular activities, one of which must be a sports activity? Why not confine it to one, but let the number of hours remain unchanged? A teacher who specialises in a particular game cannot give his full attention if half his extra-curricular activities' time is taken by another activity in which he has no interest. We should encourage specialisation in activities, rather than discourage it, especially in the secondary schools.

    Recently there was a promotion exercise for the teachers and others connected with the Education service. Though this exercise was held after an unusual delay, the promoting body has not decided on the persons to be promoted. There has been a lot of talk about the exercise in the newspapers as well as in public. Can the Minister explain why such a situation had arisen? It appears that most of the principals, being human and some being inhuman, may have made gross mistakes in the assessment of their teachers. It is my view that some solution must be found, otherwise we will have a very unhappy lot of teachers.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): I have heard several comments from my colleagues. So in fairness to the Ministry of Education, I would like to say something. It cannot be denied that over the past few years there has been a great achievement in education in Singapore. The sum allotted to the Ministry of Education for 1973-74 comes to about $300 million, both for

Column: 1039

the Main and the Development Estimates. This is to ensure that there is an all-round development in the four language streams and that all school-going children will have good teaching and proper education.

    Bilingual education is a very realistic and practical approach to a multi-lingual society in Singapore. This is a system which gives equal treatment to the various language streams. What is more important is that under this system our students will become good and rugged citizens. These are the main objectives of education which cannot be denied, but the problem is the administrative officers in the Ministry of Education headquarters and the administration in the schools. Are they capable of implementing these objectives effectively? I have received some complaints from both teachers and parents on this matter. These complaints and criticisms can be classified into four categories:

    (1) Bilingualism, in principle, is not wrong but in practice, more often than not we come across difficulties in its implementation. This is due to the lack of teachers. As a result of this shortage of qualified teachers, it is difficult to raise the standard of bilingualism, particularly the second language. Students in the Chinese stream find it difficult to follow the teaching of science and mathematics, for which English textbooks are used. That is one of the reasons why bilingualism cannot be effectively implemented. So I would like the Minister for Education to look into this problem of sufficiency of second language teachers.

    (2) The shortage of physical education teachers. We are concentrating our efforts and attention on extramural activities in the schools, but in many cases there is a shortage of PE teachers in schools. This shortage affects the extramural activities, and it also means that teachers who are not interested or not trained in physical education are dragged in to be involved in extra physical education activities. As a result, the standard of physical education does not reach the level expected. So I would

Column: 1040

like the Minister to consider the possibility of opening holiday-classes for teachers in physical education, both in terms of technique, practice and theory. This may go a long way towards alleviating the shortage of PE teachers.
